Rights","icon":"ðŸ›’","category":"Consumer Protection","description":"What to know about consumer protection laws and your rights","rights":[{"title":"Right to Fair Debt Collection","description":"Debt collectors cannot harass you, lie about what you owe, call before 8 AM or after 9 PM, or contact you at work if your employer prohibits it. They cannot threaten jail, garnishment, or arrest if it's not legal. If a debt collector violates these rules, you can sue them for damages. Request written verification of any debt.","source":"Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) of 1977","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"California has additional protections under the Rosenthal Act; strict enforcement against abuse"},{"state":"NY","note":"NY has strong debt collection protections; violations can result in damages"},{"state":"TX","note":"Follows federal FDCPA; limited additional state protections"}]},{"title":"Right to Dispute a Debt","description":"Within 30 days of receiving a debt collector's first letter, you can send a written dispute demanding they prove the debt is valid. They must then provide verification or stop collection efforts. Many debts are unverifiable or belong to someone else. Send disputes by certified mail with return receipt.","source":"Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) Â§ 809","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"FTC Cooling-Off Rule","description":"If you buy something through a door-to-door sale, telemarketing, or certain other methods, you have 3 business days to cancel and get your money back, no questions asked. The seller must provide written cancellation instructions. This applies even if you agreed to the purchase. Put cancellation in writing.","source":"Federal Trade Commission (FTC) Cooling-Off Rule (16 CFR Â§ 429)","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Truth in Lending","description":"Lenders must clearly disclose the loan terms, annual percentage rate (APR), finance charges, payment amount, and total amount you'll pay back. All terms must be in writing before you sign. Misleading disclosure of rates or fees is illegal. Compare APRs and terms before committing to a loan.","source":"Truth in Lending Act (TILA) of 1968","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"California has additional disclosure requirements; strong enforcement by Attorney General"}]},{"title":"Lemon Law Protection","description":"If your new vehicle has persistent defects that make it unsafe or unfit for its basic purpose, the manufacturer may be required to replace it or refund your money. Each state has specific rules and timeframes. Defects must be reported and given a chance to be fixed. Documentation of repair attempts is crucial.","source":"State Lemon Laws (varies by state; federal Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act also applies)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Song-Beverly Consumer Warranty Act: covers defects within 18 months or 18,000 miles; strong consumer protections"},{"state":"TX","note":"Covers new vehicles for 24 months or 24,000 miles; manufacturer-friendly with high bar for replacement"},{"state":"NY","note":"Covers defects within 2 years of purchase; requires good faith repair attempts"},{"state":"UT","note":"Covers new vehicles for 24 months or 24,000 miles; requires multiple repair attempts"},{"state":"FL","note":"Covers defects discovered within 24 months; manufacturer-friendly; narrower protections than some states"}]}]},"availableStates":["CA","FL","NY","TX","UT"]}]}],"$L4"]}],null,"$L5"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
